text:
The buildup of ice is a problem for many industries,
interfering with the performance of aircraft,
power lines, and wind turbines.
It can be time consuming and costly to remove.

So scientists are developing surfaces that
prevent ice from accumulating.

They’re making superslippery surfaces that
not only keep ice from sticking but also prevent
ice from forming in the first place.
Some use lubricants or tiny surface structures.

Now, researchers at the University of Illinois
at Chicago have made ice-resistant surfaces

using simple molecules and phase-changing
physics.

The key to this frost-resistant surface is
a family of materials that are liquid at room

temperature and solidify above the freezing
point of water.

This property leads to some interesting phase-changing
high jinks when water tries to freeze.

And researchers have dubbed these anti-icing
materials phase-switching liquids.

At frigid temperatures, when added to a surface,
the PSL forms a solid film.

When water vapor in the air condenses onto
a surface, it releases heat.

The latent heat of condensation melts the
PSL film locally to create a thin layer of
liquid underneath and around the water droplet.

See how these droplets slide around in the
melted cyclohexane on this surface?

The researchers think that it’s harder for
ice to form when the condensed droplets are

in contact with a smooth and insulating liquid
PSL film.

They tested several phase-change materials—both
in bulk form and infused into a textured surface—and

found that dimethyl sulfoxide in bulk form
worked best.

A DMSO surface resisted freezing for more
than 4 days at –15 ℃. That’s 300 times
as long as conventional superhydrophobic surfaces.

Virginia Tech’s Jonathan Boreyko, who works
with frost-resistant surfaces, called the

approach from the University of Illinois team
“very clever” and said he’d like to

see future studies investigate how exactly
frosting is being delayed.

Rukmava Chatterjee, a member of the Illinois
team, says the group is now working to make

the PSL films more durable and figure out
the best way to apply them to objects.
